questions.text: 'A' kills 'B' with a knife. Another person 'Z' saw 'A' with a knife in the park a few minutes before the murder. 'Z' gives this statement in a court of law. What kind of evidence is it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Indirect

 

Explanation

  • Indirect evidence, also known as circumstantial evidence, does not directly prove the fact in question but supports it through inference.
  • In this case, 'Z' saw 'A' with a knife shortly before the murder, which does not directly prove that 'A' killed 'B', but it is a relevant circumstance that can be linked to the crime.

Types of Evidences

Feature

Documentary Evidence

Oral Evidence

Expert Evidence

Definition

Written or printed documents produced for court inspection

Statements made before the court by witnesses

Opinion from a person specially skilled in the relevant field

Legal Admissibility

Admissible as primary evidence

Admissible; allows cross-examination

Admissible under specific conditions (Sec. 39, BSA)

Reliability

High, if properly maintained

Can vary; subject to witness credibility

High, if from a qualified expert

Specific Medical Examples

Medical certificates, hospital records, lab reports

Doctor's testimony, nurse's account of patient care

Medical examiner's report, specialist's opinion on treatment

Circumstantial evidence or indirect evidence: It is the evidence consisting of collateral facts from which an inference may be drawn and are consistent with the direct evidence, such as finding blood on the clothes of the accused.

Direct (Option A): Direct evidence provides immediate proof of a fact, such as an eyewitness seeing the murder occur. Here, 'Z' did not witness the murder itself, so the evidence is not direct.

 

Hostile (Option C): A witness becomes hostile when they deviate from their original statement or intentionally withhold information to favor the accused. There is no indication that 'Z' was hostile in this case.

 

Hearsay evidence (Option D):

  • Any evidence that is offered by a witness of which he/she does not have direct knowledge but his/her testimony is based on what others have said. For example, a relative overhearing a conversation between doctors discussing a possible misdiagnosis.
  • Since 'Z' personally saw 'A' with the knife, this is not hearsay.

questions.text: A 30 year old apparently healthy man who was carrying laxatives and enema apparatus developed abdominal pain at the airport and an x-ray was done which appears as shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Body packer syndrome

Explanation:

  • Body packer's syndrome, also called the surgical mules syndrome is a planned activity to smuggle drugs.
  • The drug to be smuggled is usually wrapped in polythene or condom, and swallowed/planted inside vagina or rectum.
  • The x-ray shows cylindrical objects which may be containers for the drugs.

Incorrect Options:

Bezoar Syndrome (Option A): It is a syndrome in which there is a tightly packed collection of something inside the stomach.Usually, bezoar occurs for a collection of hair inside the stomach, but it can be any indigestible natural/unnatural object.

Pica due to anemia (Option B): It does not present as shown in the case history.

Constipation due to fecalith (Option D): It mostly shows excessive bloating, not shown in the x ray.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents with breathlessness, declining health, and is found to have multiple metastases. She is awake, alert, and visibly anxious. The medical team assesses that aggressive chemotherapy, radiotherapy, ICU care, and mechanical ventilation would not improve her condition and may cause harm. Despite this, the patient's daughter insists on pursuing all possible life-prolonging measures, including ICU admission. What is the most appropriate next step for the physician in managing this case?

choices.text: Convene family meeting considering patient values and goals of care
Admit to ICU and initiate aggressive treatment
Discharge and shift to home palliative care

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Discharge and shift to home palliative care

Explanation:

  • Palliative care prioritizes comfort, dignity, and quality of life when curative or aggressive measures are futile.
  • In this scenario, the patient’s advanced disease, poor prognosis, and risk of harm from invasive interventions make home-based palliative care the most ethical and beneficial approach.
  • This allows symptom control, emotional support, and dignified end-of-life care in a familiar environment.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Convening a family meeting is valuable but may delay appropriate transition to comfort care and may not address immediate patient needs if clear about treatment futility.

Option B - ICU admission with aggressive treatment risks unnecessary suffering with no survival benefit.

Option D - Placebo treatment is unethical and not appropriate in end-of-life care.
